{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3530786,"name":"","username":"pigrammer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pigrammer/{size}/234083_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-17T23:37:33.305Z","cooked":"

Recently we have begun to have an issue where the navX2 gyro on our robot is not zeroed on startup. Turning off the robot and turning it back on, calling reset() or zeroYaw() in code, and even pressing the reset button physically on the gyro (more on this larer) do not do anything. This behavior is consistent with the navX2 and also a classic navX that I swapped it for.

Specifically the reset button has really weird behavior. After pressing it, the reported yaw value remains the same for a few seconds - this is expected as the gyro is rebooting. Then, it boots with a value, and begins continuously changing this value (in the same direction and at the same rate every time, as far as I could tell) until it settles on a value. Once, I saw the value go to 0 a few seconds after this, but this did not happen again.

I have tried to firmware update the navX2, but following the directions here I encountered an issue where although I held down the CAL button while plugging in the cable and only the red 3.3V LED was on, and the firmware update software showed that the device was in firmware update mode, when I clicked on the button to update the firmware it would think for a few seconds and then tell me the device was not in firmware update mode, although it clearly was. If anyone has a solution for this that would be great.

But more generally, this is really weird because we did not change anything about our code with the gyro since last year other than changing to the library provided by Studica as opposed to the old library, and did not change anything physically or firmware update the gyro. I could believe that it was caused by the library change except that the physical reset button does not work, and it is not zeroed on startup.

I even tried getting the yaw value on initialization, saving it, and then subtracting it from all future measurements to do in user code what the library is supposed to be able to do, but that did not make a difference somehow.

I have tried searching but could not find anyone with a similar problem. If someone has encountered this issue before and/or has a solution that would be greatly appreciated.

Is it letting the robot drive, is the code not building? I’ve had some experience tinkering with a NavX and MAXSwerve this past December and ran into a couple issues. I would try to see if you are having a code or a hardware issue. Adding a simple print statement to see the status of the gyro may help you degub.
These are the extent of my experience with the NavX:

NavX2-MXP always Calibrating Programming
Interesting. I wonder why someone would have put that there. I suspect that would have stopped SPI communication. So that’s why it would have worked in the NavX UI since it uses USB. Presumably if you had tried USB on the roboRIO it would have worked also.
NavX2-MXP with MAXSwerve 2025 Programming
Something I should warn you about is that some of the older NavX’s had a problem where their yaw wasn’t properly calibrated, and would result in a 20 degree drift after a few rotations. My team also ran into this issue, but we were unable to fix it (there are instructions on how to fix it online, might just be user error on our part). Maybe rotate your drivebase a few times and make sure that this isn’t an issue before you commit to the navx.
Gyro Not Zero-ing Programming
yeah. i don’t suppose the board is not horizontal, is it? that would cause this failure. otherwise, i’d suggest contacting support to get a new one: in the meantime, you could try one of the Redux gyros. They work great:
